author: AAP
title: RWC 2015: Bernard Foley kicking Wallabies towards glory |
text:
Tries are expected to be at a premium as the heavyweights go head to head in a tournament where ever-improving defences have been dominant.
Accurate goalkicking will be crucial in this weekend’s quarter-­finals and Foley is the player who can give Australia a vital edge.
Under the tutelage of kicking coach Chris Malone, he has become one of the most reliable in the game.
The pivot enjoyed a breakout game against England, crossing for two tries and kicking seven from seven for a tally of 28 points.
But that performance simply highlighted what the Wallabies already knew, and Foley backed it up with another terrific display with the boot against Wales, kicking his first five penalty attempts before botching his final shot with the game’s result assured.
According to goalkicking analysts website goalkickers.co.za, which rates the performances of all kickers based on the difficulty of their attempts, Foley has made marked progress in the past two years. The rating system is based on the difficulty of each kick, ­defined by factors such as distance, angle and game situation in which the kick is taken.
Last year, Foley was ranked 51st of all kickers in the Super Rugby despite guiding the Waratahs to their maiden title — kicking at a percentage of 77.2 but with a rating of 4.68.
During the pool stages of the World Cup, he’s missed just two of 19 attempts and has been awarded a kicker rating of 6.08.
Only Wales’ Dan Biggar (15 from 16) and France’s Morgan Parra (6/6) have better ratings of players in quarter-final teams.
Notably, All Blacks veteran five-eighth Dan Carter is no longer knocking them over with laser-like precision — and is ranked ninth of the remaining kickers, with a rating of 5.43 after missing four of 20 attempts so far.
Having watched Foley kick them to victories in consecutive weeks, his Wallabies teammates have complete faith in their No 10.
“I watch him train. I watch how much work the kickers do on the park to get to that position,” vice-captain Michael Hooper said.
“It is no fluke they are out there kicking goals and kicking well. It is a lot of hard work.
“They are the last guys out on the field often, so it’s good they get that praise and they deserve it because it’s a job that’s very difficult.”
AAP
